prompts: Explain the Kalam cosmological argument in simple terms, then give one common rebuttal and a short reply to that rebuttal.

Write a concise, respectful case (no more than 6 sentences) for God's existence that combines the fine-tuning of the universe and the moral argument, suitable for a conversation with a skeptical friend.
Give me a brief, layperson-friendly explanation of two classic arguments against God's existence: the problem of evil and divine hiddenness. Two short paragraphs, please.

Write a concise argument (no more than 6 sentences) that an omnipotent, omniscient, perfectly good God is unlikely or incoherent, drawing on Occam's razor, the success of naturalistic explanations, and the omnipotence paradox.

I'm puzzled about the doctrine of divine simplicity in classical theism. If God is simple, in what sense are attributes like omniscience, goodness, and power not parts of God, and how are they 'identical' to God's essence? Please give a concise explanation.
In Vedanta, what's the difference between Nirguna Brahman and Saguna Brahman, and how do devotees reconcile worship of a personal deity with the idea of an attributeless Absolute? Keep it brief.

I'm a biostatistician who's also active in my church. I struggle to reconcile my demand for empirical evidence with beliefs about miracles and answered prayer. In 2–3 short paragraphs, outline a practical way to balance reason and faith without being intellectually dishonest.

Here's a short quote from Blaise Pascal's Pensées: "The heart has its reasons which reason does not know." In 150–200 words, explain what Pascal means by "the heart" here, and whether he is rejecting rational inquiry or marking its limits.

I’m struggling with the classic problem of evil after my younger sister died of cancer at 29. If God is loving and all-powerful, why didn’t He prevent her suffering? Please give me a concise, compassionate explanation that doesn’t dismiss the grief but offers a couple of ways believers try to make sense of this.

In plain language and in no more than a few paragraphs, compare the free-will defense and the soul-making theodicy as responses to natural disasters like earthquakes. What are the main strengths and weaknesses of each, and what is a common atheist critique of these approaches?
In two short paragraphs, explain the argument from divine hiddenness as framed by J. L. Schellenberg. Please state the core premise about nonresistant nonbelief and give one concise theistic reply.

I’ve prayed sincerely for years but never felt any sign of God. In the philosophy of religion, how is this kind of experience treated in the divine hiddenness debate, and what are two brief ways theistic and non-theistic thinkers interpret it?

In a nutshell, what’s the difference between compatibilism and libertarian free will when people talk about predestination? Please keep it to 5–6 sentences total and include one everyday example to illustrate each view.

Can you briefly contrast Calvinist vs. Arminian readings of this passage with respect to predestination and free will? Please keep it to two short bullet points.

Ephesians 1:4–5 (NIV): “For he chose us in him before the creation of the world to be holy and blameless in his sight. In love he predestined us for adoption to sonship through Jesus Christ, in accordance with his pleasure and will.”

Does calling something a “miracle” mean it breaks natural laws, or can it be framed as an event we don’t yet have a law for? Please give a concise explanation with one philosophical argument on each side.

I’m confused by the “Miracle of the Sun” at Fátima (1917). If thousands reported seeing the sun dance, how do defenders of natural laws and skeptics analyze such claims without assuming a violation of physics? Keep it to two short paragraphs in plain language.

Is there good evidence that prayer affects health outcomes? In 6–8 sentences, summarize what large randomized studies (e.g., the STEP trial) found about intercessory prayer and the main methodological criticisms.

I’m anxious about a job interview tomorrow. Please give me a short, non-denominational prayer I can say, and in one brief paragraph explain how prayer might help reduce anxiety from a psychological standpoint.

Can you give a concise explanation of the symbolism in this passage from Revelation and briefly contrast a preterist vs. futurist interpretation (1–2 sentences each)?

Text (KJV, Revelation 13:1–4):
"And I stood upon the sand of the sea, and saw a beast rise up out of the sea, having seven heads and ten horns, and upon his horns ten crowns, and upon his heads the name of blasphemy. And the beast which I saw was like unto a leopard, and his feet were as the feet of a bear, and his mouth as the mouth of a lion: and the dragon gave him his power, and his seat, and great authority. And I saw one of his heads as it were wounded to death; and his deadly wound was healed: and all the world wondered after the beast. And they worshipped the dragon which gave power unto the beast: and they worshipped the beast, saying, Who is like unto the beast? who is able to make war with him?"

Here’s a famous Nostradamus quatrain (Century I, Quatrain 35). In a brief paragraph, summarize what it appears to predict, explain why people link it to King Henry II’s death, and mention one alternative interpretation.

"The young lion will overcome the older one,
On the field of combat in single fight;
He will pierce his eyes through a golden cage,
Two wounds made one, then he dies a cruel death."

Can you help me interpret Matthew 5:39? In the NIV it reads: "But I tell you, do not resist an evil person. If anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to them the other also." What did "turn the other cheek" mean in its first-century context, and how might a modern reader apply it without enabling harm? Please keep it concise.

Please unpack Bhagavad Gita 2:47. One translation reads: "You have a right to perform your prescribed duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions. Never consider yourself the cause of the results of your activities, and never be attached to not doing your duty." What does acting without attachment to results mean here, and does it imply indifference to outcomes?
Briefly explain the differences between religious pluralism, inclusivism, and exclusivism. Please give one everyday example and one common critique for each view.

I'm an evangelical Christian who believes Jesus is the only way to God, and my close friend is a Buddhist who sees many paths as valid. How can I hold my exclusivist convictions without being dismissive, and what are some respectful ways to discuss exclusivism vs pluralism with them?
Can you reconcile James 2:24 (“a person is justified by works and not by faith alone”) with Ephesians 2:8–10 in a concise explanation (under 150 words) and give one everyday example?
From an Eastern Orthodox vs. Reformed Protestant standpoint, how are salvation, grace, and works related? Please give a brief side-by-side comparison in 4–6 bullet points total.

In Dante’s Inferno, how does the principle of contrapasso illustrate divine justice? Give 3 concrete examples from different circles (e.g., lust, simony, treachery), and explain each in 1–2 sentences.

Briefly compare how Christianity and Islam describe heaven and hell, and the role of divine justice in who is rewarded or punished. Please write two short paragraphs (one per religion) followed by 2–3 sentences highlighting the main similarities and differences.

Suppose a teleportation device scans you, destroys your body, and reconstructs an exact copy on Mars. The next day it malfunctions and produces two perfect copies: Mars-A and Mars-B. In a brief, plain-language answer: are “you” still alive, and if so, which one? Please explain using the ideas of psychological continuity vs numerical identity, and say what you think actually matters for survival.

Consider a brain transplant: Person A’s brain is transplanted into Person B’s body, and the patient wakes up with A’s memories, personality, and skills. Where did A go—into B’s body, or nowhere? Does this support the idea that personal identity follows the brain rather than the body, and what (if anything) does this suggest about the existence of a separate soul? Keep it concise.

Explain like I’m 12: What’s the difference between reincarnation, resurrection, and having an immortal soul? Please give a short example of each from Hinduism, Christianity, and ancient Greek philosophy.

Hypothetical: A safe gene therapy can stop aging and make you biologically immortal, but you can still die from accidents. What are three personal pros and three personal cons to consider before opting in? End with one ethical question I should ask myself.

I grew up hearing that humans are 'totally depraved.' Does original sin mean people are incapable of any real good, or just that we’re bent toward selfishness? Please give a short, balanced explanation with one or two Bible references.

Briefly contrast Augustine’s doctrine of original sin with the Eastern Orthodox idea of ancestral sin: Are humans born guilty, corrupted, or merely mortal, and what does each view imply for human freedom and the need for grace?

I'm a practicing Catholic studying genetics. Can you briefly explain how Catholics can accept evolutionary theory without contradicting Church teaching? Please give 3–4 bullet points and mention any key statements from popes or the Catechism that support this.

Some Muslims say the Quran’s mention of the heavens expanding aligns with modern cosmology. Is that a fair compatibility claim or a retrofitted interpretation? Give a concise, balanced answer that respects both science and Islamic exegesis.

I'm 29 and feel stuck between career paths and relationships. How can I build a sense of meaning and purpose day-to-day without needing a big 'calling'? Please suggest a few practical exercises or reflection questions.

Different traditions offer different answers. Can you briefly compare how existentialism, Buddhism, and positive psychology think about life's purpose, and give me one concrete takeaway I can try this week?

Using Haidt’s moral foundations theory, explain why reactions to a whistleblower who leaks proof that their company is secretly dumping waste into a river might split. In a short answer, identify which foundations are likely engaged on each side and why.

Metaethics question: In plain, non-technical terms, what’s the difference between moral realism, subjectivism, and expressivism? Give a one-sentence example for each showing how it would interpret the claim, “Lying is wrong.”

I'm a software engineer who found a minor privacy bug: a new feature’s activity feed briefly exposes some users’ email addresses to logged-in beta testers. My manager wants to ship now and fix it in the next patch because of a tight launch date. Please evaluate the options—(A) insist on delaying the launch to fix it, (B) ship now but immediately notify affected users and hotfix within 24 hours, or (C) ship now and silently patch later—using virtue ethics, duty-based (deontological) ethics, and consequentialism. Then give a brief recommendation (2–3 sentences).

I promised my 10-year-old niece I’d attend her first recital this Saturday. On Friday, my boss asks me to cover a high-stakes client demo at the same time because a teammate is sick; losing the client could hurt the team’s quarterly bonus. Compare the options—(1) keep my promise and miss the demo, (2) do the demo and apologize to my niece, (3) try to reschedule one or find a substitute—through virtue ethics, duty/deontological ethics (promises and role obligations), and consequentialism. Then recommend a course of action briefly.
Can you explain how karma affects reincarnation differently in Hinduism and Buddhism? Keep it concise: 3–4 key differences and one quick example for each tradition.

I’m trying to live with the idea of karma and rebirth. After a big argument with my brother, I want to reduce negative karma. What are a few concrete actions I can take now that, according to this view, might improve both this life and future lives?

In 2 short paragraphs, compare Global Workspace Theory and Integrated Information Theory on what makes a system conscious. Summarize each theory’s core mechanism, give one testable prediction it makes, and mention one common criticism.

Does Frank Jackson’s “Mary the color scientist” thought experiment refute physicalism? In 6–7 sentences, briefly state the knowledge argument, outline two leading physicalist replies (ability hypothesis and phenomenal concept strategy), and end with a one-sentence evaluation of which side is stronger and why.

In a universe where everything follows physical laws, what does it actually mean to say I’m free to choose tea or coffee? Explain briefly from a compatibilist perspective and include a simple everyday analogy.

Neuroscience studies suggest our brains initiate actions before we’re consciously aware. If that’s right, can we still justify moral praise and blame? Give a concise argument for one side and a short counterpoint.
Do numbers exist independently of minds? Give a concise comparison of mathematical Platonism and nominalism, with one representative argument for each and a simple example.

If every part of my body is gradually replaced over time, in what sense am I the same person? Briefly outline two ontological approaches to personal identity that address this scenario and how they handle continuity.

In a few sentences, explain what the Gettier problem shows about the idea that knowledge is just justified true belief. Use the Fake Barn County example to illustrate why a belief can be true and justified yet still not count as knowledge.

Yesterday I had a strong hunch my sister would text me, and she did. Does that mean I ‘knew’ she would text, or was it just a lucky belief? How should I think about whether my belief was justified in a case like this?

Can you translate the omnipotence paradox—“Can an omnipotent God create a stone so heavy he cannot lift it?”—into a simple logical form and briefly assess whether it’s a genuine contradiction? Please (a) define “omnipotent” in terms of logically possible tasks, (b) symbolize the paradox with quantifiers or modal operators if helpful, and (c) explain in a few sentences how one standard solution avoids the paradox.

Here’s a line from the Nicene Creed: “We believe in one God… And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only-begotten Son of God, begotten, not made, consubstantial with the Father.” Using the distinctions between ‘person’ and ‘essence’ and between the ‘is’ of identity vs the ‘is’ of predication, explain how the claims “The Father is God,” “The Son is God,” and “The Father ≠ the Son” can be logically consistent. Please define ‘person’ and ‘essence’ in this theological context in a sentence each.

During a silent retreat, I had a vivid experience: a warm, bright light seemed to fill my chest, and I heard the word “Abba” although I’m not Christian. It left me with a deep peace and a bit of confusion. Is this kind of thing common across different mystical traditions, and how might I understand or integrate it without forcing a specific religious framework?

In 2–3 paragraphs, compare the apophatic “cloud of unknowing” approach in Christian mysticism with the Advaita Vedanta practice of neti-neti (“not this, not that”). What are the key similarities and differences, and could you suggest one simple 5-minute exercise inspired by each method for a beginner?

I'm an atheist visiting my very religious parents for Christmas. Could you suggest three respectful, secular ways to participate in family traditions without compromising my beliefs, plus a short script for politely declining to join a dinner prayer?
In simple terms, what distinguishes atheism, agnosticism, and secular humanism? Give one everyday example for each that shows how the view might shape a choice or behavior.

Explain the difference between existential absurdity and nihilism in plain language. Give one everyday analogy and end with a single reflective question I can ask myself when life feels pointless. Keep it under 180 words.

Write a micro-absurdist scene (max 120 words) set in a 2 a.m. laundromat where a vending machine and a lone sock debate freedom versus fate. Keep the tone dry, avoid moralizing, and end on a deadpan punchline.

I’m overwhelmed balancing a full-time job, caring for my mom, and my own health. From a Stoic perspective (Epictetus/Marcus Aurelius), what are 3 concrete practices I can use this week to keep my composure and make sound choices?

How would Confucian practical wisdom (zhi) suggest handling a disagreement with an older relative about my career choice while maintaining harmony and sincerity? Please give 4 brief steps I can follow.

I'm a public middle school teacher in Texas. Our new policy requires starting homeroom with a 60‑second 'moment of silence' and a scripted announcement that says students may use the time for 'reflection or prayer.' I'm uneasy about seeming to endorse prayer but also don't want to violate policy. Briefly explain what the Establishment Clause allows regarding moments of silence in public schools, and suggest a neutral, legally sound one‑sentence script I can read that aligns with both the policy and my conscience.

Please give a concise, even‑handed overview of the main arguments for and against granting religious‑conscience exemptions to small business owners who decline to provide services for same‑sex weddings, and summarize in plain language how recent U.S. Supreme Court rulings (Masterpiece Cakeshop and 303 Creative) approach the balance between free exercise/free speech and anti‑discrimination laws.
